primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: Jesus Christ voluntarily enters the place of ultimate human degradation and shame to undergo a substitutionary exchange, thereby liberating humanity from the crushing weight of their own misdeeds.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus consciously, deliberately, voluntarily stepped into the place of utmost humiliation.
He hid not himself from shame and spitting.
He made himself helpless in order to undergo this worst form of disgrace.

object.identificatie: The bearing of the world's shame/The liberation of the 'Slave'
tekstueel_bewijs: The shame belonged to us; the effects fell upon him.
He alone was able to take on himself the shame of the whole world.

zender.identificatie: God (as the source of the 'Exchange' and the one who justifies)
tekstueel_bewijs: God, be merciful to me a sinner... went down to his house justified.
The slave (that's you and me); the Son (that's Jesus).
You and I will never have to wear a dunce cap again.

helper.identificatie: The Holy Spirit (implied through the 'growth in grace') and the Prophet Nathan (as truth-teller)
tekstueel_bewijs: When a person feels shame before God, it is a sure sign of growth in grace.
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject (Christ) and the Sender (Father).
helper.rol_van_geest: Indwelling power enabling the 'Receiver' to eventually act in the secondary program.

tegenstander.identificatie: The 'Bad Kind of Shame' / Public Scorn / Sin / The Powerful who inflict degradation
tekstueel_bewijs: The punitive and destructive kind that is thrust upon a person by a more powerful figure.
The significance of the Cross as a sign of utter contempt.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a bad feeling but 'Godforsakenness' and 'Accursedness'—a state of being 'not fit to live' that only a divine subject can overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer, now liberated from crushing shame, is able to practice 'constructive shame' (confession and repentance) as a sign of maturity.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Believer (The Hearer)
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The ability to say 'I am ashamed' (Secondary) is explicitly grounded in Christ having already borne the 'ultimate burden' (Primary).

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God → Liberation from Shame → The Hearer
actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: Grace → Jesus ← The Powers of Degradation

voorbeelden_god_subject: He hid not his face from shame and spitting.
He took upon himself the form of a slave.
He alone was able to take on himself the shame of the whole world.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We need to recover a sense of shame.
The person steps forward and takes his punishment.
We are now able to stand upright.

voorbeelden: You ought to be ashamed of yourself.
I want to be held accountable.
I knew what my elders meant.
He alone was able to take on himself the shame.
We are now able to stand upright.
We are now able to rejoice.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Pouvoir' (Power/Ability) of Christ which then grants a new 'Pouvoir' to the hearer. It moves from human inability to divine ability.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Starts with ~S1 (modern shamelessness), moves to S2 (the reality of the Cross), shows Christ occupying S2 to move the hearer to ~S2 (healthy confession) and finally S1 (Justification).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved through the 'Exchange'—Christ takes the 'Bad Shame' so we can have the 'Good Shame'.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the sermon dwells on the 'revolting' and 'subhuman' nature of crucifixion.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. While it calls for human action (confession), it identifies Christ as the sole actant capable of dealing with the 'heavy opponent' of cosmic shame.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: King David demonstrated this in an unforgettable way... David confessed his sin.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: The shame belonged to us; the effects fell upon him.
Jesus... voluntarily stepped into the place of utmost humiliation.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: David and McNamara are used as models of 'healthy shame', but they are subordinated to the work of Christ.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides this by noting David's confession is a 'sign of growth in grace' (God's work).

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and empowerment; the 'dunce cap' is removed by another.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the cultural need for shame to the theological provision of Christ is seamless.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: The slave hath sinned and the son hath suffered... he has taken our place.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit (Grace) provides the 'Pouvoir' to confess without being crushed.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Severe; sin leads to being 'Godforsaken' and 'not fit to live'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God/Christ as the primary Subject of the salvific action, placing the hearer in the role of the Receiver who is subsequently empowered to act.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly heavy on 'Pouvoir' (which is good for grace).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The move from 'cannot' to 'can' because of Christ's 'did' is theologically perfect.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The opponent (shame/degradation) is already presented with visceral intensity.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This is a masterclass in grace-oriented preaching. It addresses a human psychological need but anchors the solution entirely in the objective, substitutionary work of Christ.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'dunce cap' metaphor; Greimas shows that the dunce cap is an actantial Opponent that only the Subject (Christ) can remove.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegese explains the meaning of 'shame' in Isaiah; Greimas shows how that shame functions as the 'Object' Christ carries for the 'Receiver'.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'strength' to confess is not a human virtue but a 'modal competency' granted by the primary narrative program.

appendices.notities: The sermon avoids the 'If-Then' trap of moralism by grounding the 'Then' (our confession) in the 'Because' (Christ's work).
